title: How to convince my parents to let me join an online school - Quora

response.answer_text: I can’t guarantee that you will be able convince your mom to allow you to do an online school, but here are some things to prepare to discuss with her. Part One: Explain the benefits of online school In the question details, you say that you will be happier if you do online school. That’s nice, but why would you be happier? You’ll need to support that claim with some specific details. What other benefits are there? Happiness is nice, but what else does online school have to offer? Those benefits aren’t necessarily the same for everyone, depending on what their other options are and what kind of student they are. Some possibilities could be: flexible scheduling, working at your own pace, being away from bullies at your local school, not being around people who are sick (if you have health problems), no traffic/commute to school, better education (if your local schools are not very good). It’s really on you to come up with a few ways in which online school would be better than a local school. I think you should have at least 3 of them. Part Two: Address Mom’s concerns about online school In the question details, you mention that she doesn’t want you to be home alone all day. [EDIT: Chelle Gordon states in her answer that K12, the specific school you mentioned, requires that an adult be home with the student and serve as a learning coach. So you might need to find a different online school or totally drop the discussion now.] This is a big concern, and you need to take it seriously. How independent and responsible are you? How much time do you spend home alone right now? How much of a self-starter are you when it comes to getting your chores done around the house? Can your mom really trust you to attend your online classes and complete your assignments on your own, when she’s at work? You’ll need to demonstrate to her that you are capable of managing yourself and your education. I used to provide speech therapy online to cyber school students. I worked for a speech therapy company that contracted with a lot of different schools. For some schools, it was a requirement that there was an adult at home with the student during our speech therapy sessions. They didn’t have to participate in the session, but they had to be home. And I can tell you that my students from that school had much better attendance and participation than the students from another school that didn’t have that requirement. I remember one student in particular who never showed up — not once — the entire time she was on my caseload. Her mom was at work and couldn’t get her to attend her sessions. When my husband and I decided that online school would be a good choice for our son, I quit my job. Even though I had been working online from home, we didn’t trust him to work independently during the time that I was with my students. Supervising his online education is my job now. Most of the families I know who have students in online school, whether I knew them from my job or through parent groups, have a parent at home pretty much full-time. She might also be concerned that being home alone all day will not be good for you socially and emotionally. That is also a legitimate concern, especially since she won’t be taking you on field trips or meetups with other online or home-schooling families. Tell her your plans for addressing your social needs. Do you have some activities outside of school that you’ll be participating in? Some examples could be a team sport, a church youth group, scouts, martial arts, etc. You will need to have some kind of regular contact with people outside of your house. This is easier for some people than others.

Although this question was asked over a year ago, maybe someone will read the answers now and get some good help from what’s written. My daughter is starting her sophomore year in a few days. Last week I told her we really need to go get your school clothes. Usually she is thrilled about clothes shopping opportunities. Right then she told me she had been thinking about doing online school this year. Our school district has a great, easily accessed online school program. She told me her reasons she would feel better doing online school full time. (She had taken one online class last semester) .She had so much anxiety last year about school she would worry about stuff and make herself sick in all different ways and either not go to school, or need to come home from school. Each day of school she missed made it so much harder to keep up with her tough classes that require some instruction, like physics and algebra. If she missed two days of a unit she would fail the unit test. The teachers don’t make time to help kids that need extra attention. If she needs an extra hour of help a week that’s not gonna happen. Teachers here have too many students for each kid to get the extra help if they need it. Although she is popular, and has no problems making friends, there is still unhealthy drama, harassment and abuse committed on her by male and female students. There are frequent violent physical fights at school, it’s been a problem since 7th grade, especially between female students that make her , and me, fear for her safety. She was once pushed forward by another girl and told to “go beat her down”. She backed out quickly: before she was touched by another student. But how scary! She feels pressure to spend at least an hour each morning straightening her hair and applying makeup just right, so she isn’t made fun of for looking”ratchet”. I feel bad for her. I have known all this, but I thought she was willing to stay for the social part of school. She has good friends, fun, was on homecoming court, goes to all sport activities. She isn’t willing to hurt every day any more. She can see her friends every day, just later. She can still go to games. She will still be enrolled in the district and be able to attend all sport events and dances. She still has a student body card. Still gets class pictures. Still has a teacher for each class. She can go to the physical online academy school building and get help or study or get materials she may need, any or every day. There are core teachers there full time. A principal. A wellness counselor and a traditional school counselor that helps with school planning and college prep stuff. We met with the principal of the online academy yesterday. It was amazing. MY daughter is excited for school to start. Instead of new school clothes she got a new school laptop that is hers, not the families, not a tablet or chrome. There are way better electives available through the online academy than at the traditional high school. And if at any time she wants to take a class at the physical school for some reason she can. Like if it’s hard to do her Spanish 2 class without a class of people to work with, face to face, she can just take that class at the high school. But there Are language instructors at the online school too. She can go to the building and work with them too, or online. Her school starts the same as the physical HS. September 5th. She will go there that day, get her pictures done and student body card. Meet all the teachers and all the other online students, who she will interact with online sometimes. She can ask questions of more experienced online students. And after that day she will only go there if she wants for help or for testing. Otherwise she will make her schedule at home. We made an agreement that she would have a work plan for each week so she doesn’t struggle or procrastinate. She won’t be able to go out with friends unless she’s up to date with work in each class. But that’s the only restriction. She can get a job now if she wants, without restrictions on day hours like other HS students. She can hang with me on days and go do cool stuff. We can go to all kinds of tours, shows, plays, galleries, museums. There is so much to learn and see OUTSIDE the school building. I feel very optimistic about the opportunities this experience opens for my daughter. I hope my family’s experience with choosing the online school option can help people and give people ideas about how to approach the situation. Oh, there were challenges with this decision. Her father and step father both think this online school plan is a bad idea. They think it means she is dropping out of school. All I can suggest is inviting them to the meeting with principal and orientation so they can get a better idea about what’s happening. Also fully disclose to them the reasons why traditional isn’t working for you. Maybe they don’t know your struggles. I think ,deep in their hearts ,they just want you to succeed and be happy. The men in our problem seemed to believe that since they had to “suck it up and suffer through high school” ( these were the exact words) they think our kids should be forced to do the same. I defended the choice. I told reminded them that 25/ 30 years ago there were not these amazing options for students. We didn’t have the same kinds of problems in schools as our kids face daily. We did have gigantic classes where teachers didn’t have time for us. Things have changed and our children can have a better education and education experience than we did. I did tell my ex husband that just because he suffered doesn’t mean our daughter needs to suffer. Sounds like a him problem, not a her problem. Good luck! Online school is an awesome option for some students

Your parents’ job is to prepare you for life and good decision making, and to make decisions for you until you’re emotionally and mentally mature enough to make those decisions on your own. A decision about your schooling should not be made by a child. That’s why college is for 18 year olds and not younger. Any younger than that and your frontal lobe isn’t capable of really processing the long term implications of your decision. In other words, it’s not your job to decide how you go to school. If you say they’re avoiding the discussion, my guess is they’ve already answered you and you just want to open a discussion they don’t want to have. Let it go and move forward with your life. As for online school, it’s a bad plan unless it’s the only option left. In a world where the fastest growing addiction is internet addiction, we’re now throwing our children into the thick of that addiction for hours every day in the name of education. It’s equivalent to educating alcoholics in a bar. Online schools have been shown to have significantly lower scores on college entrance exams and higher dropout rates. https://credo.stanford.edu/pdfs/OnlineCharterStudyFinal2015.pdf

Well, what does your proposal look like right now? Can you point to a reliable source that says online schooling is a legal option in your state and district? Can you make a comprehensive list of the testing that would be required, how the tests must be administered, and how much they cost? And of any other legal requirements? Where are the instructional materials you plan to use? How much do they cost? Have you done placement testing to determine what grade level you’re at right now in every subject? Do you have a plan for each subject, one that involves supplementary resources if you find yourself struggling with a subject? Do you know how to tell if you’re struggling with a subject? How do you plan to assess the instructional plan you’re using? How will you know if it isn’t working well for you? What’s your Plan B if that turns out to be the case? How much does that Plan B cost? What about physical education? How do you plan to incorporate movement into every day? Do you know whether Advanced Placement classes are available for online students? If so, how much do they cost? Have you done research on the admissions requirements of, say, the top three colleges you’d like to go to? You don’t want to plan your education around your state’s minimum requirements, only to discover in your senior year that none of the colleges you want will accept you without two years of a foreign language. How do you plan to get unbiased assessments of your achievements, your strengths, and your weaknesses? … or are you trying to convince your parents by saying, “But I waaaant to!”

First of all I would like to ask what type of online school it is. Like college or extra curricular as that's important. However I will answer for both. For college school: I will be right at home so you won't have to worry about me partying in dorms or any dangerous activities instead of homework.Most careers will still consider an online degree the same as any other degree so my years will still be fine.Possibly offer them to add a restriction on your computer to make sure that it's used only for the class. This would be a last resort but very convincing so that they can trust you with it.Extra curricular: Same as the last bullet for college.You can increase your chances of getting into a good college if you have gotten some classes or credits done online.It's a more useful use of time then playing games or out partying.Similar reasons for both but I mean they could all qualify for each other.

Tyler, I try to go with the younger generation — when you’re an uncle and not a dad you can risk it. But I just can’t see my way clear; Mom is right on this one. Under the best circumstances, online schools can be tricky because social development is a big, though mostly unofficial, part of education. This is true when you are not the king of the dance — maybe especially when you are not king of the dance. Success in forthcoming life will require you to be experienced at dealing with assholes, and where better to learn than in school? And Tyler, Mom knows and I know and you know there is a lot more shit online than in school, so there are real questions about what you would do for recess and physical education. You and I know a lot of shit goes down at school too. But the structure and presence of authority does place limits. I don’t know what grade you are in, but with a name like Tyler Glissendorf, I think there is a very good chance that some August when you report to school, you will be a stud, and it would be a shame to waste it online.

Online school works for a lot of people but it is not for everybody. You have to do work just like in your local public school. My 13 year old son did not get bullied but I have had problems with the school district and there was too much drama in the school. I would recommend online school if you plan on doing the work and have a learning coach that is going to be home with you.  I would say tell your parents what is going on at school. and pour out your heart and tell them why you want to do this so bad! Tell them the pros and cons of online schooling, and tell them why you feel its the best thing for you to do. Also ask your parents to see why they does not want you to do it. Best of luck!

Show her that you learn better by reading, watching videos, hearing discussions rather than sitting somewhere for most of your day watching others struggle with face to face ‘learning'. I pulled both my kids out of brick and mortar when they were in 2nd and 5th. They had serious issues being bullied and confined - by staff! My eldest has gone back to brick and mortar for social reasons and my youngest will return because he needs the discipline of having peers and a one on one teacher. Tell your mother that you'd like to try it for a semester and see how you do. You must have very strong self-starting abilities and be able to complete hard assignments by yourself. If you can do this, you'll flourish in homeschooling/online schooling. If you know you need to be constantly pushed, one semester won't mess you up too bad but give you working knowledge about the options.

K12 requires an adult to be with you. One of my kids was in the K12 program for half of a school year. We learned two things: His brain works well with computerized educationThe K12 program is awfulFurther, we learned that the program requires a “learning coach,” an adult, to supervise your education. There are a lot of things that they completely don’t explain. They leave it to the learning coach to explain how something works. This is pretty lousy, as there is no requirement that the learning coach be well-educated. Fortunately, I knew everything they left out of his 4th grade program. But if you don’t have a learning coach, who is going to help you with the stuff they leave out? This might not be relevant, but anyone reading should also know this: K12 doesn’t deal well with disabilities. I could go on and on about how poorly they handled that situation. Finally, while the advertisements say that they provide (a few) social opportunities, they never actually provided any. Apparently, that only applies if you live in a large, metro area. Even then, a few events a year will not replace daily/weekly socialization with peers. If you are having difficulty socializing with your peers, try talking to someone about that. Try a school counselor, your parents, or a trusted teacher.

All the matter is of placating parents for doing something which is totally out of their ideology of learning since every new thing which is out of our ideology seems strange to us, it is quite obvious of parents to not to give consent for on line learning. First and far most you explain them your specific reason to prefer on line learning over traditional classroom. Though advantages of on line learning are not hidden anymore those provides a range of benefits such anytime, anywhere learning. However it can be isolated and by passage of time you may loose your interest to peruse any degree as till now it is considered to the students who are working or working professionals who want to enhance their skills, secondly I will suggest you to present your reasons and assurance to your parents that whatever course you will begin will sustain and complete rigorously. Moreover, you can explain how on line study is going broaden your horizon of knowledge.Tell them the success ratio of people in terms of job, society and life after doing on line courses, Best of luck.

Try creating a presentation for them. Include a well-thought-out Pro/Con chart. Research the online school(s) you are interested in. If your parents can trust you to be home alone every day while they are at work, and they believe that you are a good student that can effectively work without close supervision, then you might have a chance. You might also talk to your teachers and tell them what you are wanting to do, and see if they offer you any advice.

Write them a well planned out proposal. Do some research on the pro’s of taking online classes. List each reason with a personal statement about how this directly pertains to you in a positive way. Lastly, explain that this is a choice you have thought long and hard about. Again explain your reasoning and the good that will come out of the choice you have made.

What do you believe would prevent your parents from wanting to prevent you from changing schools? You make a very good argument FOR switching to an online program, and it sounds like you could be able to present your concerns and desires. Just be prepared for what you think their reasons would be to not agree; but more importantly, LISTEN. Give their concerns weight and merit, even if you don’t agree. This is your opportunity to be learn and practice adult negotiation skills

Consistent ideas on its benefits and promising results would help them contemplate. You didn't write what you've been studying lately i.e which grade and why you want to opt for online schooling when school learning is diverse and effective too. Sorry dear, difficult to guide further. Thanks

Before you can overcome your parents’ objections, you need to know what they are first. Ask your parents their reasons for not letting you join online school. Then, do your homework to answer the objections with rational facts. Nothing wins a parent over more than objective research. Good luck!

Don't try to give smart answers rather speak about your own conviction in online school. If your conviction is great they will be convinced. But if you lack clarity you should first of all work on that and then talk to your parents
Could you get a job at McDonald’s and go to a Catholic school? Or could you go to a charter school. Staying at home can be difficult and isolating and one has to be a self-starter to do that.
The solution is not here, it is between you and your parents, write down all the evidence carefully for your case and then talk to them
What are you, 5? Suck it up, buttercup. Life is not a party. If it's so easy for you, then take as many classes as you can, and graduate early.
